title: Cobb & Co. (restaurant)
text:
Cobb & Co. is a New Zealand <a href="family%20restaurant">family restaurant</a> <a href="restaurant%20chain">chain</a>.
It is New Zealand's oldest surviving family restaurant chain, having opened its first branch in 1973. Its name derives from the <a href="Cobb%20%26amp%3B%20Co.%20%28New%20Zealand%29">Cobb & Co</a> stagecoach business originally founded in Australia in the 19th century by <a href="Freeman%20Cobb">Freeman Cobb</a>, although the chain has no direct historical connection with that company.
The chain's trademark feature is a <a href="stagecoach">stagecoach</a> theme with red <a href="Western%20saloon">saloon</a>-style doors. It offers a <a href="casual%20dining">casual dining</a> menu with steak, hamburgers, seafood, and similar items. It is known for its non-alcoholic <a href="mocktail">mocktail</a> drinks.
History.
The chain was created by the hotel division of New Zealand Breweries (now <a href="Lion%20%28Australasian%20company%29">Lion</a>). Their first Cobb & Co opened in 1973 in their <a href="Auckland">Auckland</a> South Pacific Hotel.
At its peak in the 1980s there were 37 Cobb & Co restaurants around New Zealand, but the chain had shrunk to eight branches: six in regional towns and centres in the <a href="North%20Island">North Island</a> (<a href="Levin%2C%20New%20Zealand">Levin</a>, <a href="New%20Plymouth">New Plymouth</a>, <a href="Porirua">Porirua</a>, <a href="Rotorua">Rotorua</a>, <a href="Taupo">Taupo</a>, and <a href="Whakatane">Whakatane</a>), and two cities in the <a href="South%20Island">South Island</a> (<a href="Christchurch">Christchurch</a> and <a href="Dunedin">Dunedin</a>).
In the 1980s it ran a series of comedic television commercials featuring British actor <a href="David%20Jason">David Jason</a>.
In 2012 the chain was purchased by Sue and Ben Gower, who had originally been franchisees of the Tauranga branch. In 2016, plans to re-expand the then-dwindling chain were announced.
Controversy arose in 2017 when a newly relaunched branch located in the historic <a href="Dunedin%20Railway%20Station">Dunedin Railway Station</a> applied for a licence to include <a href="slot%20machines">slot machines</a> on its premises, with the <a href="Problem%20Gambling%20Foundation%20of%20New%20Zealand">Problem Gambling Foundation</a> criticising the presence of gambling machines in a family restaurant.
